section: \section{Determination of the spectrum of   N=2 D=8    supergravity}

\section {A digression about the TQFT for the 3-form}
 

It is actually an interesting question to investigate whether a TQFT for
the 3-form alone has some interest, in particular for the study of
8-dimensional manifolds with $Spin(7) $ holonomies and of  7-dimensional
manifolds with $G_2$  holonomies. This was suggested as early as in \cite{bakasi}. 
%Following a suggestion of Witten, 
We would like to  briefly sketch new ideas relative
to this question and indicate a possible hint  for getting an interacting theory for the 
3-form, when topological
gravity is decoupled. 


We have seen in the previous section that the  TQFT multiplet for a
3-form   is basically made of the following fields: 
\bea
\label{gen}
C_3, 2B_2, 2A _1, 2S,
\lambda^\alpha_\mu,2\chi^\alpha 
\eea
These fields are those that   propagate in the TQFT, provided one does a
suitable gauge-fixing.
 %Due to the untwisting,  they   have a physical interpretation as
%fields with a physical spin--statistic relation. 
  Spinorial notations have already been
used for  the Fermi fields
that are topological ghosts.

 We understood in the previous section that the   gravitino
$\lambda^\alpha_\mu$ (a 1-form which a spinorial index)  is made of  
topological ghosts, including  the self-dual antighost
$\chi_{\mu\nu\rho\sigma^+}$ of $C_3$  The multiplet (\ref{gen}) does not involve a
metric. 
If we follow the conventional pattern for building a TQFT, we introduce an external
metric  $g_{\mu\nu}$, and do  a topological BRST invariant gauge-fixing. In this way, we   
can  get a free TQFT action for the fields in Eq.~(\ref{gen}). The action contains the
term:    
 \begin{eqnarray}
 \int d^8x \ s ( \chi^{\mu\nu\rho\sigma^+}(\partial _{[\sigma }
B_{\mu\nu\rho]}+  H_{\mu\nu\rho\sigma^+})) 
\cr =
 \int d^8x \  ( |dB_3+^*dB_3 |^2+ \ldots  )  
\cr=
 \int d^8x  \  \sqrt {g} (
g^{\mu\mu'}g^{\nu\nu'}g^{\rho\rho'}g^{\sigma\sigma'}
 \partial _{[\sigma} B_{\mu\nu\rho]}
 \partial _{[\sigma'} B_{\mu'\nu'\rho']}+\ldots ) 
%\nonumber 
\end{eqnarray}
The dots are easy to compute. We can dimensionally reduce the fields and get a TQFT  in
seven dimensions,  for a 3-form and a 2-form. The self-duality condition in eight
dimensions is replaced by the following one  in
seven dimensions,  
which also stands for     35 conditions:
\begin{eqnarray}
\label{bog}
dC_3+^*dB_2=0
\end{eqnarray}
   Imposing these conditions in a BRST-invariant
way   is    allowed by the fact that
$C_3$ and
$B_2$ carry 20 and 15 degrees of freedom modulo gauge transformations in
seven dimensions. Eq. (\ref{bog}) is a generalization of
the well-known Bogomolny equation.

If 
we can define a metric
$g_{ij}(B_3)$ in seven dimensions, which depends on the 3-form, and  use it  for
the 
$^*$
Hodge operation,   we    can trigger interactions between the
forms, by defining   the following action:
\begin{eqnarray}
 \int d^7x s ( \chi^{ijk  } (
(dB_2+^*dC_3)_{ijk  }+ H_{ijk  })\cr= 
 \int  d^7x   ( |dB_2+^*dC_3 |^2+ \ldots  ) 
\cr =
 \int d^7x  \sqrt {g}  (g^{ii'}g^{jj '}g^{kk'} 
 \ \partial _{[i } B_{jk ]} \ 
 \partial _{[i'} B_{j'k' ]} \cr+
g^{ii'}g^{jj '}g^{kk'}g^{ll'}
\ \partial _{[i } C_{jkl]}
 \partial _{[i'} C_{j'k'l']}+\ldots )
%\nonumber
\end{eqnarray}
The dots   involve   the metric dependence  of the 3-form. 
This action is    analogous in spirit   to that of supersymmetric
mechanics in curved space. The subtlety is to find the relevant configuration space  of the 
3-form for defining the path integral.

 A further reduction in six dimensions determines   
theories with self-dual 2-forms. Such TQFTs have been directly studied in six dimensions,
and  interesting correspondences with supersymmetry have already been found
\cite{west}.

There is another topological field theory, which we can obtain by
directly starting from    the topological action $\int _{M_7} C_3\wedge
dC_3$.  For certain manifolds, one can  give
a special role to the direction $x^7$ and write:
\begin{eqnarray}
\int _{M_7} C_3\wedge dC_3=
 \int _{M_7} d^7x ( C_{7ab  }\epsilon^{ab cdef }\partial_{[c} C_{def]  }+
\epsilon^{ab cdef } C_{abc  } \partial_7 C_{def  }  )
%\nonumber
\end{eqnarray}
Here, $a,b,c,d,e,f$ stand for 6-dimensional indices.

Generalizing  the analysis  of the Chern--Simons theory in three dimensions
\cite{cswitten},      formal manipulations suggest that the
7-dimensional theory with the   above action  might   also describe  a theory    
  in six dimensions, depending of a 2-form, with an
action   of the type:
\begin{eqnarray} 
 \int  _{M_6}  d^6x   \sqrt {g} 
\ g^{aa'}g^{bb '}g^{cc'} \ 
 \partial _{[a } B_{bc] }\ 
 \partial _{[a'} B_{b'c'] } +{\rm WZZ \ action}
%\nonumber
\end{eqnarray}
A heuristic argument  can be done  by  formally integrating out $ C_{7ab  }$,  
solving the constraint
$ \partial _{[a } B_{bc ]}=0$, and picking a slice at $x^7=cte$. Eventually, the
6d-metric depends on the 2-form,
$g^{aa'}=g^{aa'}(dB_2)$, and we have a non trivial model.  The observables in the
seven dimensional theory  theory are obtained from the flux of the 3-form on a
3-cycle:
\begin{eqnarray}
 exp  \int \int \int _{\Gamma_3}C_{ijk} dx^i \wedge dx^j \wedge dx^k  
%\nonumber
\end{eqnarray}
and
\begin{eqnarray}
 exp  \int \int _{\Gamma_2}B_{ij} dx^i \wedge dx^j  
%\nonumber
\end{eqnarray}
  We leave the  investigation of these theories  for future work.

\section {Conclusion}

This paper shows that, in eight  dimensions, the TQFT for a metric, a 2-form and a
3-form reproduces in a twisted form (at least in the quadratic
approximation)   $N=2 $  $D=8$   supergravity in a $Spin(7)$-invariant gravitational
background. This result it quite interesting.    In particular, it 
gives an alternative definition for local supersymmetry. It    suppresses the
apparently impossible challenge    of closing the algebra of infinitesimal
transformations of supergravities by mean of  auxiliary fields  and   of   getting  a
group structure   for the   transformations of  supergravity. We now understand   the
fact that the latter    ``close modulo equations of motions" as   a  trivial  consequence
of  the   determination of  a TQFT    by enforcing self--duality equations in a
BRST invariant way. The correspondence that we have found between the ``maximal"
supergravity (and thus of all its descendants)  and    topological gravity is consistently
supported by the existing relationship between superstrings and topological
sigma-models \cite{green}. 


Many dimensional reductions of the TQFT that we have exhibited can be   thought of.
 We  foresee theories in seven and six  dimensions, where    $ G_2  \subset Spin(7)  \subset
SO(8)$ plays an important role \cite{Bilal}, as well as  potentially interesting models 
  in 2, 1 and 0 dimensions. In the latter case, we
  expect a generalization of the DVV  matrix model \cite{dvv} by gravitational
terms,   stemming  from the topological 8-dimensional action. They might be relevant
to the recent works \cite{vafa}. Another interesting idea   is that, since the most
general   supersymmetric theory, which is $N=1$ $D=11$ supergravity, seems of
topological origin, it may also  naturally encode by dimensional
reduction the idea of stochastic quantization,   which  is known to have the structure of a TQFT
and  to   efficiently  regularize many of the problems that one encounters in the quantization of
4-dimensional Yang--Mills theories \cite{lbz}. The 8-dimensional gravitational theory  can
be also coupled to a non Abelian Yang--Mills theory, which allows us to consider other
types of models by dimensional reduction, and perhaps, to find   a
description of the octonionic superstring
\cite{stro}.


We added   the following  remark. The
construction of a TQFT for a 3-form in  eight dimensions can be done
independently of the context of topological gravity.  It still  needs $Spin(7)$
holonomy manifolds, but  the  metric is no longer a dynamical field.   One thus get 
models of the topological type that  depend  on a gravitino and seem  to  contain  
topological observables.     Such   models, which  seems related to
the``Chern--Simons action" $\int (C_3\w dC_3)$  in seven dimensions, might be of
interest for the study of 7- and/or 8-dimensional manifolds.
